awd_titl_txt: First-principles studies of relativistic spin interactions and torques
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports computational and theoretical research and education aimed at better understanding the mechanisms by which relativistic magnetic effects manifest themselves in the properties of magnetic materials and nanostructures. The ability to understand these mechanisms is critical for further progress and continued innovation in information technology. The focus of this project is on the fundamental physics relevant for emerging electronic device technologies that exploit electron spin in addition to, or instead of its electric charge. Part of this research will involve investigations of the properties of specific magnetic materials that are promising for use in such devices. The project will also study the effects arising at interfaces between different materials, which enable the operation of current and future devices. Overall, it will advance the broader goal of designing materials and nanoscale devices with desired properties through computer simulations based on fundamental principles of quantum mechanics.

The project will achieve broader impacts by advancing the fundamental theory of magnetism, facilitating the design of novel magnetoelectronic devices, and through the development of new computational tools, which will be made available to the broader computational materials research community. The research will involve graduate students, who will be educated in modern electronic structure, magnetism and transport theory, and will gain experience in the use and development of state-of-the-art electronic-structure and transport codes.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports computational and theoretical research and education aimed at better understanding relativistic magnetic interactions in magnetic materials and nanostructures, and their effects on transport properties. This research is based on density-functional electronic structure theory, and includes the development of computational tools for the description of relativistic magnetic interactions and spin torques based on linear-response and nonequilibrium Green's function techniques. The project will focus on elucidating the mechanisms of magnetocrystalline anisotropy in metallic antiferromagnets, electronic structure of magnetic materials of current interest, such as magnetically doped topological insulators and half-metallic ferromagnets, and spin-orbit torques in non-centrosymmetric metals and ferromagnet/heavy-metal bilayers. The central feature of this research is realistic, material-specific treatment of disorder and temperature-dependent spin fluctuations.

The project will achieve broader impacts by advancing the fundamental theory of magnetism, facilitating the design of novel magnetoelectronic devices, and through the development of new computational tools, which will be made available to the broader computational materials research community. The research will involve graduate students, who will be educated in modern electronic structure, magnetism and transport theory, and will gain experience in the use and development of state-of-the-art electronic-structure and transport codes.

por.por_cntn:
This theoretical project was focused on investigating the relativistic magnetic interactions and spin-orbit transport effects in systems of current interest in magnetoelectronics, including the magnetic and electronic properties of technologically promising magnetic materials and the mechanisms through which electric currents in magnetic nanostructures can be used to manipulate the magnetization. This research is based on the first-principles electronic structure theory, which aims to predict the properties of materials using computer simulations based on the fundamental quantum-mechanical equations. Studies carried out under this project contribute to the broader goal of designing novel devices harnessing the electron spin for information processing and storage.

Magnetocrystalline anisotropy determines how strongly the magnetization of a material is favored to align in a certain way with respect to the crystallographic axes and is one of the key parameters in applications and device engineering. Several groups of alloys have been studied in this project. MnPt is an antiferromagnetic compound that exhibits a spin reorientation transition as a function of temperature, and off-stoichiometric Mn-Pt alloys also display spin reorientations as a function of concentration. This behavior was qualitatively reproduced and interpreted in terms of the underlying electronic structure. Magnetic anisotropy of a MnPt/MgO interface and its tuning by voltage were also studied, and the results suggest that such films can serve as a versatile platform for magnetic memory and antiferromagnonic applications. It was suggested that CuMnAs with perpendicular magnetic anisotropy could be used as an active material for antiferromagnetic memory cells, storing information in the antiferromagnetic domain state while relying on the surface magnetization for writing and readout. It was predicted that easy-axis anisotropy, which is favorable for some applications, can be achieved in bulk CuMnAs by substituting a fraction of As atoms by other elements. The magnetic properties of Fe2P-based alloys have also studied, and an explanation was proposed for the sharp enhancement of the Curie temperature on alloying with certain elements. Co-alloying of Fe2P with Co or Ni and Si was suggested as a strategy for maximizing the magnetocrystalline anisotropy at and above room temperature. Co2MnSi is a ferromagnetic compound which is ideally a half-metal, i.e., a metal with a 100% spin polarization of the conduction electrons. For applications it is important to understand how substitutional and thermal spin disorder affect the electronic structure and spin polarization. A study of these aspects has been performed in this project.

Spin-orbit torque is an effect observed in magnetic nanostructures comprised of a thin ferromagnetic layer in contact with a layer of a heavy metal with strong spin-orbit coupling, such as platinum. An electric current flowing in such a device generates a torque on the magnetization of the ferromagnet, which can be used for switching in magnetic memory chips or exciting precession in spin torque nano-oscillators. In this project, computational tools for the studies of spin-orbit torques were developed and implemented as part of the freely available Questaal software package. These tools were used to study the angular dependence of spin-orbit torque in Co/Pt bilayers, revealing a higher-order component in addition to the usual dampinglike and fieldlike terms. The thickness dependence of spin-orbit torque and magnetoresistance in Co/Pt and Co/Au bilayers was also studied, revealing large contributions to both the dampinglike torque and magnetoresistance coming from the interfaces rather than from the spin-Hall effect in the bulk of the heavy metal, which is often assumed to be the dominant mechanism.

A generalized magnetoelectronic circuit theory for magnetic nanostructures with spin-nonconserving interfaces was developed and applied to the problem of spin relaxation at magnetic interfaces. This theory accounts for various mechanisms responsible for spin-flip scattering and provides a relation between the so-called spin memory loss parameter, which can be measured experimentally, and the calculable spin-flip transmission and reflection probabilities. Calculations were performed for several magnetic interfaces and compared with experimental data.

This project provided educational experiences in computational materials theory for graduate students at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. A PhD thesis was completed and defended based on this research. The results have been disseminated through publications in professional journals and conference presentations.
